title.narrative: UNIDO LKDF, facilitation and innovative skills development
UNIDO LKDF, facilitering och innovativ kompetensutveckling

description.narrative:
UNIDO has requested support to their Learning and Knowledge Development Facility, LKDF, 2.0 for the facilitation of demand-driven and innovative skills development in the era of automation and digitization. The Sida contribution amounts to 17 MSEK, 3,4 MSEK per year for five years, 2020-2024. The activity period runs up to June 2025. The first disbursement will be effectuated upon the signature of the agreement. LKDF was initiated by Sida and UNIDO in 2012 and Sida supported the facility between 2013-2016.
With around one third of the world’s 1.8 billion young people neither in employment, education, or training (abbreviated NEET), youth unemployment is one of pressing global issues in the 21st century. Furthermore, one billion more youth will enter the job market in the next decade, but only 40% are expected to find jobs that currently exist. This implies that 600 million jobs will have to be created in 10 years, only to keep pace with projected youth employment rates. Covid-19 may firther aggravate the situation.
One of the main reasons for high youth unemployment in many developing countries and countries in transition is a growing mismatch between the supply and demand of industrial skills. In particular, the content and quality of Technical and Vocational Education and Training programmes in many countries does not match the private sector’s demands. As a result, graduates cannot find jobs while employers cannot find skilled personnel. This further exacerbates the issue of youth unemployment and negatively impacts economic development due to foregone investments.
The LKDF promotes a modality that has proven successful in fostering youth employment through industrial skills training: Public Private Development Partnerships (PPDP), which is a way of delivering and funding public services with wider development impact and building local self-reliance and markets. The investment, risks, responsibilities and rewards are shared between the public sector, the private sector and a development partner. PPDPs are used in areas where poverty reduction cannot be achieved by separating private sector actors, the public sector and development agencies, and where all these actors share a common goal. To make a PPDP successful, it has to create benefits for all parties.
The value proposition is that the private sector partners ensure that the curricula and the training are relevant for the industry, while the technical partners, such as UNIDO, are uniquely positioned to bring together stakeholders from the public sector, the private sector and the development sector. As a result of the above, PPDPs are well-positioned to serve as role models for curricula accreditation and emulation by other TVET Centers.
The LKDF 2.0, will use the Market Systems Development (MSD) Approach to achieve systemic change in PPDPs with the expected outcome that demand-oriented vocational training is offered. The following outputs are planned; (1) Plans for partnerships that bridge the skills gap market failure are delivered; (2) Market Systems Development assessments are produced to inform new PPDPs; (3) Knowledge generated from PPDP projects is made available through an expanded e-platform and face-to-face meetings, and; (4) Training proposals with innovative and future oriented training content are developed. The project will commence with a six months' long inception phase during which a number of strategic documents will be elaborated for approval before the second disbursement: a more developed results' framework and theory of change based on an inclusive system and risk analysis and the actual demand from the industry; an outreach strategy on how to to attract businesses and other actors, including other donors, to join, as well as a communication strategy; the terms of reference for the project steering committee, and; a draft workplan for the first year of implementation. In addition, a cross-departemental working group will be set up at UNIDO.
The intervention’s total budget is 1,781,445 EUR, out of which UNIDO will fund 200,000 EUR and Sida contributes with 17 MSEK. The project is expected to contribute to employment and to Sustainable Development Goals number 4 (education), 9 (innovation) and 17 (partnerships).

UNIDO har inkommit med en förfrågan om stöd till deras kunskaps- och lärandeplattform, Learning and Knowledge Development Facility 2.0, för facilitering av innovativ och efterfrågestyrd kompetensutveckling inom ramen för den globala omställningen som sker till följd av automatisering och digitalisering. Sidas bidrag uppgår till 17 MSEK, 3,4 MSEK per år mellan 2020-2024. Aktivitetsperioden löper till juni 2025. Den första utbetalningen görs i samband med signerandet av avtalet. Sida var med och startade LKDF tillsammans med UNIDO 2012 och stöttade faciliteten 2013-2016.
Omkring en tredjedel av världens 1,8 miljarder unga människor är utan sysselsättning (anställning, skola eller annan utbildning) och ungdomsarbetslösheten är en av de stora globala frågorna för 2000-talet. En miljard unga kommer dessutom att komma ut på arbetsmarknaden under kommande tioårsperiod men bara 40% av dem förväntas kunna få ett av de nu existerande jobben. Det innebär att 600 miljoner jobb måste skapas inom tio år bara för att undvika att den nuvarande ungdomsarbetslösheten ökar. Beroende på effekterna av Covid-19 kan situationen bli ännu värre.
En av de främsta anledningarna till hög ungdomsarbetslöshet i flera utvecklingsländer och länder i transition är ett ökande glapp mellan utbud och efterfrågan på industriella färdigheter. Innehållet och kvalitén av yrkesutbildningsprogrammen matchar inte näringslivets behov av kompetens. Unga nyutexaminerade får således inte jobb medan arbetsgivarna inte hittar kvalificerad personal. Det spär i sin tur på problemen med ungdomsarbetslöshet och påverkar den ekonomiska utvecklingen negativt till följd av uteblivna investeringar.
LKDF 2.0 bygger på en modalitet som har visat sig vara framgångsrik vad gäller att bidra till sysselsättning bland unga genom utbildning inom industriella färdigheter, nämligen Public Private Development Partnerships, PPDPs, eller partnerskap mellan den offentliga och privata sektorn. PPDPs är ett sätt att leverera och finansiera tjänster tillhandahållna av den offentliga sektorn med ett större och bredare utvecklingsgenomslag, bygga oberoende och stärka lokala marknader. Investeringsriskerna, ansvaret och belöningarna delas mellan den offentliga sektorn, den privata sektorn och samarbetsparten. PPDPs används på områden där fattigdomsminskning inte kan uppnås om inte aktörer från näringslivet, den offentliga sektorn och utvecklingsaktörer går samman och där alla har ett gemensamt mål. För att en PPDP ska lyckas måste samarbetet bidra till positiva resultat för samtliga parter.
Värdet med samarbetet eller samverkan är att den privata sektorn säkerställer att läroplaner och kurser är relevanta för industrin medan den tekniska parten, i det här fallet UNIDO, kan föra samman aktörer från det offentliga, näringslivet och utvecklingsaktörer såsom Sida. PPDPs utgör därmed en god grund för att inspirera till läroplanens ackreditering och att andra yrkesskolor strävar efter att efterlikna.
LKDF 2.0 kommer att använda en marknadsansats för att bidra till systemförändring vad gäller PPDPs och den förväntade effekten är att efterfrågestyrd yrkesutbildning erbjuds och sysselsättningen ökar. Följande resultat förväntas: (1) Planer för partnerskap som överbryggar marknadsstörningen som har med kompetensglappet att göra levereras; (2) Bedömningar av marknadssystemutveckling produceras för att informera nya PPDPs; (3) Kunskap/lärdomar från PPDPs tillgängliggörs genom en utökad e-plattform och fysiska möten, och; (4) Kurs/utbildningsförslag med innovativa och framtidsorienterat innehåll utvecklas. Projektet inleds med en sex månader lång inceptionsfas under vilken ett antal strategiska dokument ska tas fram för godkännande innan den andra utbetalningen sker: ett mer utvecklat resultatramverk och förändringsteori baserad på en inkluderande system- och riskanalys och den faktiska efterfrågan från industrin; en strategi för "outreach" för att locka företag och andra aktörer att delta, inklusive andra givare, och en kommunikationsstrategi; en arbetsbeskrivning för projektets styrkommitté, och; förslag på en arbetsplan för det första året av genomförande. Dessutom ska en avdelningsövergripande arbetsgrupp etableras på UNIDO.
Insatsens totala budget är 1,781,445 EUR varav UNIDO finansierar 200,000 EUR och Sida bidrar med 17 MSEK. Projektet förväntas bidra till sysselsättning och till de globala målen 4 (utbildning), 9 (innovation) och 17 (partnerskap).

The development objective of LKDF 2.0 is to contribute to establishing inclusive, sustainable, and innovative market oriented vocational training systems and job creation in Africa and elsewhere in the era of digitilisation and automation by facilitating knowledge sharing and supporting a wider innovative approach for PPDPs in skills development. The proposal from UNIDO is to through an MSD diagnostic, which will take place during the inception phase, elaborate the theory of change based on a thorough analysis involving stakeholders and identify targets and indicators for measuring achievements linked to he following three strategic priority areas: i) advancing economic competitiveness, ii) creating shared prosperity, and iii) safeguarding the environment. The LKDF 2.0 will directly and indirectly provide support to governments, private sector, training institutions, students and trainees, current and future employees as well as investors to build stronger local economies, create jobs and improve working conditions. The intended end result of the intervention is to offer a strong TVET sector with increased efficiency, productivity, quality and competitiveness: students and trainees will improve their technical skills in line with market needs and will be able to apply them to find decent employments in fields linked to their improved skills. The following indicative outputs are suggested: 1. Partnerships that bridge the skills gap, a market failure, are supported; 2. Market Systems Development approach implemented in the development of new PPDPs; 3. Knowledge generated from PPDP projects is shared through an expanded e-platform and face-to-face meetings; 4. Innovation is promoted by developing future oriented training programmes. During the inception phase, a more elaborated theory of change and results' framework will be developed as well as a risk analysis. It will also take into account the effects or possible effects of the corona pandemic on the project.

description.narrative: There has been no formal reporting yet however UNIDO commisioned a survey as well as a paper during the initial phase of LKDF 2.0. The survey was a joint collaboration between UNIDO's LKDF and the European Training Foundation (ETF). It was a global survey, carried out between May and July, to collect information from industries to explore the economic impact of COVID-19 and measures put in place by enterprises. The survey specifically addressed whether and how COVID-19 is impacting skills needs of enterprises and measures adopted to up-skill and re-skill workers to better face emergency needs and future prospects. It focused on three dimensions: i) the economic impact of COVID-19 on industrial enterprises, ii) the impact on skills and measures adopted by enterprises, and iii) safety at work and measures adopted by enterprises. A total of 334 companies responded to the survey, the majority from the manufacturing, utilities, trade and transportation sectors. Most companies (32% of respondents) were large enterprises with more than 249 employees, followed by small companies (28%) with 10 to 49 employees and medium size (23%) companies. The conclusions drawn from the survey are that enterprises recognize skills as a major issue when it comes to ensuring business development and continuity, in particular to face pressures generated by expected changes to production processes and business delivery, and ensure adequate skills of the personnel, in particular when expecting to lay off staff in the percentage of 21-30%. Also, the pandemic has changed and increased companies’ needs for skills and accelerated demand, but it has not changed what kind of skills they need, whether access to information and strategies for skills development, re-skilling and up-skilling. Furthermore, some major issues important to explore further in the future and discuss with both enterprises and public authorities were identified; diversity of public measures, clear communication strategies, the need to learn from innovators, and uplifting the role of skills and skills development. Overall, the conclusions of the survey points to the importance of ensuring more advocacy and awareness raising on the role of skills for enterprise development, and bring more evidence on how investment in skills, re-skilling and up-skilling is key for enterprise competitiveness and development. The concept paper, "Green Industrial Skills for a Sustainable Future", was commissoned by LKDF of UNIDO to explain the relevance of skills to enable the green transformation in the industrial sector, to examine what upcoming trends in greening the industry in developing countries imply for the necessary skills, what kind of skills/competencies are expected to play a role in greening the industry, and what interventions may be necessary to develop such skills. Lastly, drawing on experiences with such interventions in developing countries, it highlights what the pre-requisites are for effective skill development programs. Insights provided by the report seek to guide policy intervention to meet the demand for green skills needed to both effectively operate and to develop green technologies. The findings of the survey and the concept paper were discussed at the LKDF Forum 6-8 October 2020 which focused on the transition to a green economy and the need for green skills. Conclusions from the Forum will be further processed by LKDF and inform the design of its future activities to make it as effective and efficient as possible in achieving its overall objective: to contribute to establishing inclusive, sustainable, and innovative market oriented vocational training systems and job creation in Africa and elsewhere in the era of digitilisation and automation by facilitating knowledge sharing and supporting a wider innovative approach for Public Private Development Partnerships, PPDPs, in skills development.
